item.title: Iran has voted in a reformist president — but change remains distant
item.description: Despite Pezeshkian's stated support for relaxing things like headscarf penalties, Iran-focused human rights groups are not optimistic.

item.title: U.S. Officials Say Russia Is Unlikely to Take Much More Ukrainian Territory
item.description: Russian forces continue to inflict pain, but NATO leaders gathering in Washington can say that their efforts to strengthen Ukraine are working.

item.title: NATO’s 75th anniversary summit in Washington clouded by political chaos - The Washington Post
item.description:
1. NATO’s 75th anniversary summit in Washington clouded by political chaos  The Washington Post
  2. Before Biden can save Ukraine, he must use the NATO summit to save himself  CNN
  3. The world wasn't ready for Trump in 2016. It's not making that mistake this time.  POLITICO
  4. As NATO Convenes, Leaders Worry About a Hole in Its Center  The New York Times
  5. NATO Summit Puts Biden's Fitness Under a Microscope  The Wall Street Journal

item.title: Modi bear hugs Putin in Moscow, marking deep ties between Russia and India
item.description: The visit shows India will maintain deep ties with Russia despite Washington’s efforts to woo Prime Minister Narendra Modi and isolate President Vladimir Putin.

item.title: Nato’s 2023 military spending produced about 233m metric tonnes of CO2 – report
item.description:
Report says member states poured $1.34tn into their militaries last year – an increase of $126bn from 2022

As leaders from member countries gather to mark the 75th anniversary of Nato in Washington DC, researchers are warning that their military budgets are eroding the climate, producing an estimated 233m metric tonnes of greenhouse gas, more planet-heating pollution than some entire countries.

“Our research shows that military spending increases greenhouse gas emissions, diverts critical finance from climate action, and consolidates an arms trade that fuels instability during climate breakdown,” says a new report from three international research and advocacy groups, the UK’s Transnational Institute and Tipping Point North South, and the Netherlands’ Stop Wapenhandel.

Continue reading...
